docs.lead_paragraph: Eighteen years after the passage of sweeping legislation to clean up the worst of the nation's toxic waste dumps, much of the job remains undone. American companies will have to spend billions of dollars in coming years to decontaminate the most polluted Superfund sites. But that is not at all obvious from scouring the companies' annual financial reports and filings. Many companies, including General Electric and Viacom, only hint at their obligations in their filings and annual reports, leaving the people who invest in their stocks, live near their properties and work in their factories in the dark about when they plan to make amends -- and how much they expect to spend.

headline.main: Cleaning Up in the Dark; Companies Disclose Little About Costs of Toxic Sites

docs.abstract: Most companies fail to report what they expect to spend to clean up sites that are known to be polluted, even though Federal securities laws and accounting rules require them to do so; executives claim that quantifying these costs is nearly impossible; companies including giants like General Electric and Viacom only hint at their obligations in their filings and annual reports, leaving people who invest in their stocks, live near their properties and work in their factories in the dark about when they plan to make amends, and how much they expect to spend; only 37 percent of 1,359 official Superfund sites have been cleaned up in 18 years since passage of sweeping bill; American companies will have to spend billions of dollars in coming years to finish job of decontaminating most polluted Superfund sites; variety of environmentalists, labor advocates, scientists and insurance industry executives are demanding that companies identify each site Government expects them to help fix and provide their best estimate of what cleanup might cost; photos; map; chart (L)
docs.snippet: Eighteen years after the passage of sweeping legislation to clean up the worst of the nation's toxic waste dumps, much of the job remains undone. American companies will have to spend billions of dollars in coming years to decontaminate the most...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gearing up for a donnybrook on tobacco legislation next week, the Senate Finance Committee today considered using part of the revenues that would be raised from an increase in cigarette taxes to give a tax break to self-employed workers and workers whose employers do not pay for medical insurance. The committee, asserting its jurisdiction over tax and trade legislation, also seemed likely to propose increasing the tax on cigarettes in a way that would drive up the price faster than the main bill that is before the Senate.

headline.main: Panel Looks at Using Part of Tobacco Tax for Self-Employed

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee weighs using part of revenues that would be raised from increasing cigarette taxes to give tax break to people who must buy own health insurance; Sen John H Chafee says consensus has developed to place excise tax directly on each pack of cigarettes, move likely to cause cigarette prices to rise faster than they would under tobacco bill proposed by Sen John McCain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A casual observer might have been excused for feeling confused. On the floor of the Senate, Democrats were rising to applaud legislation proposed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican who is facing a fierce battle for re-election this fall. Things, of course, are not always what they seem in Congress. Today, the Democrats had come to praise the bill -- a measure to help breast cancer patients -- even as they were maneuvering to block it as part of a broader scheme to force a vote on their own sweeping measure to overhaul practices by managed care companies.

headline.main: Senate Democrats Praise a Bill by D'Amato, Then Try to Bury It

docs.abstract: Democrats praise Sen Alfonse M D'Amato's bill to help breast cancer patients, even as they maneuver to block it as part of broader scheme to force vote on their own measure to overhaul practices by managed care companies; Democrats fail to get vote on their bill from Republican Senate leadership, but they succeed in preventing vote on D'Amato's bill, which would require insurance companies to pay for broader array of services for breast cancer patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A doctors' group has accused insurance companies of sex discrimination for covering the impotence pill Viagra but not birth control for women. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists yesterday urged Congress to require insurers that pay for prescription drugs to cover contraception as well. Contraception is a medical necessity, said Dr. Anita Nelson, a spokeswoman for the doctors' group meeting this week in New Orleans.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Doctors Accuse Insurers Of Bias Against Women

docs.abstract: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, meeting, New Orleans, accuses health insurers of sex discrimination for covering impotence pill Viagra but not birth control for women; urges Congress to require insurers that pay for prescription drugs to cover contraceptives (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SO, a nice chat about mental illness,'' the director Alan J. Pakula said yesterday, settling in for an interview in his apartment on the Upper East Side. ''What a nice way to start the day.'' There was cinnamon-flavored coffee and far less sarcasm in Mr. Pakula's opening line than might be imagined. The director of ''All the President's Men'' and ''Sophie's Choice'' does, after all, tell strangers on airplanes that he's a psychiatrist. ''If you say you're a filmmaker, they say, 'What's Jane Fonda like?' '' he said. ''If you say you're a psychiatrist, it's amazing how people tell you the story of their lives. Or, they're terrified.'' And, of course, silent.

headline.main: A Filmmaker's Family Faces Mental Illness

docs.abstract: Filmmaker Alan J Pakula and his wife, Hannah, discuss the mental illness of Robert O Boorstin, Mrs Pakula's son and Mr Pakula's stepson; Boorstin, a former New York Times reporter, is senior adviser to Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin and is working to get insurers to cover biologically based mental illnesses the way they would other illnesses; has prevailed on Pakulas to give a lunch at Tavern on the Green with National Alliance for the Mentally Ill in effort to 'influence the influential'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan consensus has emerged in Congress on the need for legislation to define and protect the rights of patients and to regulate managed-care companies, which provide health insurance for most Americans. But the details of such legislation have caused sharp disagreements inside the Republican Party, as more Republicans join Democrats in demanding action this year.

headline.main: Bipartisan Support Grows For Managed Care Patients

docs.abstract: Bipartisan consensus emerges in Congress on need for legislation to define and protect rights of patients and to regulate managed-care companies, which provide health insurance for most Americans; in House, groups of 12 Republicans working under auspices of Speaker Newt Gingrich, is drafting legislation to protect patients' rights; more than 80 Republicans and 140 Democrats have endorsed separate, more comprehensive bill introduced by Repr Charlie Norwood, conservative Republican from Georgia (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 73, John Curran has made a decision about where he wants to live next. He will be moving when he turns 75 from his one-bedroom co-op on East 76th Street to a new retirement community in New Jersey called Seabrook Village, in the Monmouth County town of Tinton Falls. ''My health is good,'' Mr. Curran said, ''but I'm getting leery of living by myself. When I move I want to forget my worries about taking care of myself. It will be up to them to take care of me to the day I die.''

headline.main: New York Area Retirees Get More Housing Choices

docs.abstract: Middle-income people of retirement age are getting wider choice of independent-living accommodations in New York area; expansion is also under way in pure assisted-living developments, in which residents usually get meals and help with daily living tasks; most active-adult leisure communities in area are in New Jersey beyond typical commuting distance to New York City; new retirement communities have recently opened closer to northern New Jersey's population centers; photos; rendering (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST over two years ago Northrop Grumman closed its operations at the 2,900-acre Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant here, laying off or transferring the last of 3,000 workers and leaving behind 1.1 million square feet of industrial and office space and two runways. Grumman and its successor, Northrop Grumman, , had been leasing the property from the Navy and assembling and testing military aircraft in this rural corner of the Town of Riverhead for 42 years.

headline.main: In the Region/Long Island; Riverhead Considers 2 Offers on 2,900-Acre Site

docs.abstract: Riverhead, NY, is set to get 2,900-acre former weapons plan site for free from Navy, has two bidders vying for property; First Industrial Realty Trust has offered $17 million for 550 acres containing industrial and office buildings, runway and development potential for more buildings; Mentmore Holdings Corp unit seeks entire parcel for $35 million, with town getting 25 percent share of future profits; map; photo (In the Region/Long Island) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CARL HATHAWAY was sitting on the geyser when it erupted. Hathaway & Associates, the Rowayton, Conn., money management company he runs, was one of the largest institutional holders in Entremed Inc., a small biotechnology company, when its stock rocketed from $12.06 to as high as $85 last Monday on reports that it was developing a possible cure for cancer.

headline.main: Feeling a Bit Like a Laboratory Mouse?

docs.abstract: Hazards of investing in biotechnology stocks discussed in light of sharp rise in Entremed Inc stock on reports company is developing possible cancer cure; many biotechnology stocks indexes have yet to recover to their 1991 and 92 peaks; graphs; photo (M)
